newsitem.title: USA: Minn. lawmakers approve minimum wage, pay bills.
newsitem.headline: Minn. lawmakers approve minimum wage, pay bills.

text.p: Minnesota lawmakers approved an increase in the minimum wage and pay raises for several levels of state employees, including themselves, during a special session Tuesday.
Gov. Arne Carlson said he would sign the measures. The pay bill adjusts the salary ranges for agency heads for the first time since 1987, he noted.
The minimum-wage bill approved by the House and Senate provides for an increase of 90 cents per hour, effective January 1.
The bill raises the minimum wage to $4.90 per hour for smaller employers and $5.15 per hour for larger employers.
Carlson said he supported the pay increase because he was concerned about a "brain drain" of high-level staff from Minnesota agencies to better paying positions in the private sector.
The bill abolishes existing salary ranges for agency heads and replaces them with salary limits expressed as a percentage of the governor's salary.
The measure also increases salaries for constitutional officers, state judges, legislators, administrative law judges and compensation judges.
Legislators, whose positions are considered part time, will receive a five percent salary increase from the current $29,500 to $30,975.
